prompt.prompt:
Read the clinical scenario below
List the significant issues as brief, single-line statements. 
When multiple issues might be related by a clinical entity, combine them into one concise issue. 
Each issue must be 60 characters or fewer. 
Please ensure the list of issues isn't numbered.
Please ensure there isn't a trailing full stop at the end of each issue
Please only generate 2-3 issues for most patients.
For complex patients, perhaps 5 issues, for very complex patients 7. 
Use medical words where possible. 

Clinical Scenario:
{{text}}

Clinical Summary:
Fictional Clinical Dictation – Obstetric/Gynaecological Consultation  Patient Details:  - Name: [Fictional Name]  - Age: 25 years  - Weight: 160 kg | BMI: 60  - Gravida: 5 (Para: 4, Living: 4, Miscarriages: 1)  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents with a 2-week history of worsening lower abdominal pain and irregular vaginal bleeding. She reports associated dizziness but denies fever, vomiting, or urinary symptoms.  History of Presenting Complaint:  - The pain is described as sharp, intermittent, and localized to the right iliac fossa.  - Bleeding is dark, intermittent, and heavier than spotting but less than a normal period.  - No history of trauma or recent intercourse.  - Last menstrual period (LMP) was 6 weeks ago, but cycles are usually irregular (every 5-8 weeks).  - She has a positive home pregnancy test 3 weeks ago but has not yet had formal antenatal care.  Past Medical History:  - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 3 years ago, on metformin)  - Hypertension (on lisinopril, switched to methyldopa in early pregnancy)  - Previous gestational diabetes (last pregnancy)  - Depression (on sertraline)  Past Surgical History:  - Caesarean section x 2 (last one 2 years ago for fetal distress)  - Laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy (age 20, benign cyst)  Gynaecological History:  - Menarche at age 12  - Dysmenorrhea since teens, managed with NSAIDs  - No history of STIs (last screen negative 1 year ago)  - Contraception: Previously used Depo-Provera, currently none  Drug History:  - Metformin 1g BD  - Methyldopa 250mg TDS  - Sertraline 50mg OD  - PRN ibuprofen for pain  Allergies:  - No known drug allergies  Social History:  - Occupation: Part-time retail assistant  - Smokes 5 cigarettes/day (reduced from 10 during pregnancy)  - No alcohol or recreational drugs  - Lives with partner and 4 children (ages 1, 3, 5, 7)  - Limited social support; financial stressors reported  Patient’s Ideas, Concerns & Expectations:  - Ideas: Worried this may be another miscarriage or ectopic pregnancy.  - Concerns: Fears needing another caesarean or complications due to weight.  - Expectations: Wants confirmation of pregnancy viability and pain management.  Examination Findings:  - General: Obese, mildly tachycardic (HR 100), BP 140/90  - Abdomen: Soft, tender in right iliac fossa, no guarding/rebound  - Speculum: Small amount of dark blood in vault, cervix closed  - Bimanual: Uterus slightly enlarged (8-week size), right adnexal tenderness, no palpable mass  - Bedside ultrasound (difficult due to BMI): No intrauterine gestational sac seen, possible right adnexal mass  Differential Diagnoses:  1. Ectopic pregnancy (high suspicion given pain, bleeding, adnexal tenderness, no IUGS on scan)  2. Threatened miscarriage (less likely given adnexal findings)  3. Haemorrhagic ovarian cyst (history of cysts, but high β-hCG makes ectopic more likely)  Management Plan:  1. Urgent serum β-hCG (quantitative) and progesterone.  2. Formal transvaginal ultrasound (despite BMI limitations) to assess for ectopic pregnancy.  3. Admit for observation given haemodynamic risk (tachycardia, pain).  4. Consult obstetrics/gynaecology team for possible methotrexate if ectopic confirmed.  5. Diabetic control optimisation (switch to insulin if pregnancy continues).  6. Counselling: Risks of rupture, need for close monitoring, smoking cessation support.  Follow-Up:  - Review β-hCG trends and scan results within 24 hours.  - If stable, consider outpatient follow-up with early pregnancy unit.  - Long-term: Discuss weight management, contraception post-resolution.  Impression:  High suspicion of ectopic pregnancy in a high-risk patient (obesity, prior caesareans, diabetes). Expedited management required to prevent rupture.  ---  End of Dictation (For testing purposes only – no real patient data or medical advice intended.)

response:
Ectopic pregnancy with right adnexal tenderness  
Obesity (BMI 60) with type 2 diabetes and hypertension  
Previous caesarean sections and ovarian cystectomy  
Irregular vaginal bleeding and positive pregnancy test  
Social stressors and smoking during pregnancy
textContent:
AI: DeepSeek (deepseek-chat)

Use medical words where possible.

She reports associated dizziness but denies fever, vomiting, or urinary symptoms. Formal transvaginal ultrasound (despite BMI limitations) to assess for ectopic pregnancy.  3. Admit for observation given haemodynamic risk (tachycardia, pain).  4. Follow-Up:  - Review β-hCG trends and scan results within 24 hours.  - If stable, consider outpatient follow-up with early pregnancy unit.  - Long-term: Discuss weight management, contraception post-resolution.  Impression:  High suspicion of ectopic pregnancy in a high-risk patient (obesity, prior caesareans, diabetes). Expedited management required to prevent rupture.  ---  End of Dictation (For testing purposes only – no real patient data or medical advice intended.)"
}

A: Ectopic pregnancy with right adnexal tenderness  
Obesity (BMI 60) with type 2 diabetes and hypertension  
Previous caesarean sections and ovarian cystectomy  
Irregular vaginal bleeding and positive pregnancy test  
Social stressors and smoking during pregnancy
